clean_story: Nighttime brain movies.  Sleep’s hidden workshop. "Dreaming" comes from the Old English drēam, meaning both "joyful music" and "vision seen in sleep"—like your mind composing a silent symphony while the body rests. Most assume dreams are just random noise—but they’re more like a nightshift data cleanup. Your brain replays daily experiences, trims useless details,  and stitches memories into long-term storage. Here’s the mechanism:During REM sleep, your brain’s visual cortex lights up like a projector,  while the prefrontal cortex—the "logic manager"—goes offline. That’s why dreams feel real but make no sense:your inner director is asleep at the wheel. Take lucid dreaming—where people realize they’re dreaming and sometimes control the plot. Studies show it activates the same brain areas as waking self-awareness,  proving consciousness isn’t tied to open eyes. Even animals dream. Rats replay maze routes in their sleep,  and dogs twitch as if chasing phantom squirrels. Their brains follow the same REM patterns as ours. Three related subjects are sleep paralysis mechanics, how blind people dream, and why we forget 90% of dreams.
